interpGrp.interp: Bed with Long Feet and Insect Traps
Crossing hands on belly: respect, behave obsequiously
Face in hands: sorrow, despair, crying
Hem of garments on eyes: crying
Pointing with index finger to inscriptions (Manicula): directing the reading
Sitting with crossed legs/feet: exerting authority /judge role/princely behaviour
Hand 1: early, final long <s> and middle <s> rotunda, insular <d>, <st> ligature, enlarged gothic <a>, initial <v> and middle <u>, dotless <i>, macron
May Fest at Marke’s court: gentlemen’s pastimes: Cgm 51, f. 4rb 9-46; Ranke, 587-626
May Fest at Marke’s court: ladies at banquet: Cgm 51, f. 4rb 9-46; Ranke, 587-626
Blanscheflur and Riwalin falling in love: ladies at the tournament: Cgm 51, f. 4va 26-5ra 16; Ranke, 652-732
Blanscheflur and Riwalin falling in love: knights at the tournament: Cgm 51, f. 4va 26-5ra 16; Ranke, 652-732
Riwalin’s fight against Marke’s enemies: Cgm 51, f. 8rb 1-24; Ranke, 1119-1142
Blanscheflur and the schoolmistress: Cgm 51, f. 8va 37-9ra 9; Ranke, 1199-1257
Blanscheflur and the schoolmistress visit the wounded Riwalin: Cgm 51, f. 9ra 18-rb 30; Ranke, 1266-1321
Blanscheflur and Riwalin sleeping together: Cgm 51, f. 9rb 17-39; Ranke, 1308-1330
A messenger informs Riwalin of Morgan’s attack: Cgm 51, f. 9va 40-vb 2; Ranke, 1373-1379
Blanscheflur reveals her pregnancy to Riwalin: Cgm 51, f. 9vb 40-44, 12ra 1-vb 15; Ranke, 1418-1565
Riwalin’s farewell to Marke: Cgm 51, f. 12vb 16-27; Ranke, 1566-1577
Blanscheflur and Riwalin sailing towards Parmenie: Cgm 51, f. 12vb 28-34; Ranke, 1578-1584
Rual welcomes Blanscheflur and Riwalin: Cgm 51, f. 12vb 35-13rb 7; Ranke, 1585-1637
Blanscheflur and Riwalin get married: Cgm 51, f. 13rb 8-10; Ranke, 1638-1640
Rual leaves with Blanscheflur: Cgm 51, f. 13rb 11-25; Ranke, 1641-1655
Riwalin killed in battle; his corpse brought back: Cgm 51, f. 13rb 34-va15; Ranke, 1664-1688
A messenger announces Riwalin’s death to Blanscheflur: Cgm 51 ff.13va39-13vb27; Ranke 1712-1742
Tristan’s birth and Blanscheflur’s death: Cgm 51 ff.13vb28-37; Ranke 1743-1750
Floräte feigns giving birth to Tristan: Cgm 51 ff.14vb39-43; Ranke 1911-1945
Tristan's baptism: Cgm51, ff. 16ra41-16va5; Ranke vv. 1955-2002
Tristan's education in liberal and chivalric arts: Cgm51, ff. 17ra1-40; Ranke vv. 2083-2122
Tristan's kidnapping: Cgm51, ff. 17rb25-18ra17; Ranke vv. 2149-2269
Tristan finds Rual and introduces him to Marke: Cgm 51 f. 27vb 30-28ra7; Ranke 3993-4015
Rual appears again before the King: Cgm 51 f. 28rb 8-21; Ranke 4062-4075
Rual shows Blanscheflur’s ring: Cgm 51 f. 28rb 41-29 ra 32; Ranke 4095-4332
Tristan and his companions ride to the tournament: Cgm 51 f. 34vb 2-24; Ranke 5046-5068
Tristan and Rual take leave of King Marke: Cgm 51 f. 35ra 30-va 5; Ranke 5118-5171
Tristan sailing towards Parmenie: Cgm 51 f. 35va 6-10; Ranke 5172-5176
Floräte welcomes Tristan: Cgm 51 f. 35vb 23-36ra 18; Ranke 5227-5266
Tristan meets Morgan’s huntsmen: Cgm 51 f. 36rb 16-va 19; Ranke 5309-5357
Tristan smashes Morgan’s head with the sword: Cgm 51 f. 38ra 25-34; Ranke 5449-5458
Tristan and Rual fight against Morgan’s army: Cgm 51 f. 38vb 10-39ra 6; Ranke 5567-5608
Tristan takes off his armour: Cgm 51 f. 38vb 10-39ra 6; Ranke 5609-5616
Tristan enfeoffs Rual: Cgm 51 f. 39vb 8-40ra 32; Ranke 5742-5811
Tristan bids farewell to Rual and rides off: Cgm 51 f. 39vb 8-40rb 21-36; Ranke 5845-5860
Tristan meets Morold demanding the children of Cornwall: Cgm 51 f. 41ra 40-va 4; Ranke 6007-6062
Tristan and Morold sail towards the island of the duel: Cgm 51 f. 45vb 11-39, 47ra1-43; Ranke 6721-6790
Tristan and Morold’s duel on horseback: Cgm 51 f. 47rb 41-va 23; Ranke 6833-6861
Duel with the sword: Tristan beheads Morold: Cgm 51 f. 48va 1-vb 24; Ranke 7016-7085
Tristan comes back alone on Morold’s boat: Cgm 51 f. 48vb 25-28; Ranke 7086-7089
A physician takes care of the poisoned Tristan: Cgm 51 f. 49vb 5-29; Ranke 7254-7278
Tristan crosses the sea with seven companions: Cgm 51 f. 50ra 43-va 9; Ranke 7339-7402
Tristan sails alone towards Develin, playing the harp: Cgm 51 f. 51ra 19-va 41; Ranke 7503-7614
A physician gives Tristran a drug: Cgm 51 f. 52ra 5-18; Ranke 7678-7691
Tantris teaches Princess Isolde to play the harp: Cgm 51 f. 53vb 5-54ra 12; Ranke 7962-8034
Queen Isoit gives Tristan the antidote to the poison: Cgm 51 f. 53va 10-vb 4; Ranke 7911-7961
Tristan cuts out the dragon’s tongue: Cgm 51 f. 59vb 7-15; Ranke 9056-9064
The seneschal feigns attacking the dragon: Cgm 51 f. 59vb 44-60va 4; Ranke 9093-9184
The seneschal carries the dragon’s head to town: Cgm 51 f. 60va 5-37; Ranke 9211-9253
The queen, Isolde and Brangäne find the beheaded dragon: Cgm 51 f. 61ra 5-35; Ranke 9317-9347
The queen, Isolde and Brangäne find Tristan in the pond: Cgm 51 f. 61rb 10-va36; Ranke 9366-9435
Brangäne, the Queen and Tristan ride away: Cgm 51 f. 62ra 8-15; Ranke 9493-9500
Isolde tries to kill Tristan bathing in the tub: Cgm 51 f. 64vb 27-65rb 20; Ranke 10138-10232
Brangäne reproaches Isolde: Cgm 51 f. 64vb 18-66rb 12; Ranke 10358-10456
Tristan asks Brangäne for a trick to meet Isolde again: Cgm 51 f. 75ra 24-va 26; Ranke 14386-14495
Tristan throws the twig into the stream: Cgm 51 f. 75va 29-32; Ranke 14498-14501
Tristan and Isolde embrace in the orchard: Cgm 51 f. 75va 39-51; Ranke 14508-14520
Melot leads King Marke to the orchard: Cgm 51 f. 77ra 17-26; Ranke 14590-14599
Marke and Melot, on the olive-tree, spy on Tristan and Isolde: Cgm 51 f. 77ra 33-78va 36; Ranke 14607-14906
Marke questions Isolde on his suspicions: Cgm 51 f. 78vb 18-79ra 46; Ranke 14946-15027
Marke entrusts Tristan with the guardianship of Isolde: Cgm 51 f. 79ra 48-rb 3; Ranke 15029-15035
Melot spills the flour on the floor: Cgm 51 f. 79rb 47-va 30; Ranke 15117-15153
Tristan jumps onto Isolde’s bed: Cgm 51 f. 79vb 5-20; Ranke 15174-15189
Tristan’s wound opens and bleeds: Cgm 51 f. 79vb 21-32; Ranke 15190-15201
Marke discovers traces of blood in Isolde’s bed: Cgm 51 f. 79vb 36-80ra 7; Ranke 15205-15225
Marke summons the council of princes and prelates: Cgm 51 f. 80va 3-81ra 8; Ranke 15325-15421
Isolde appears at the trial: Cgm 51 f. 81ra 9-81va 1; Ranke 15422-15517
Tristan holds Isolde and feigns a fall to embrace her: Cgm 51 f. 81va 35-vb 48; Ranke 15553-15621
Isolde takes the oath: Cgm 51 f. 83rb 15-40; Ranke 15697-15723
Isolde shows the bishop her unarmed hand: Cgm 51 f. 83ra 15-19; Ranke 15637-15641
Gilan shows Petitcriu to Tristan: Cgm 51 f. 83vb 3-84rb 2; Ranke 15791-15888
Tristan rides away in search of Urgan: Cgm 51 f. 84va 22-26; Ranke 15958-15962
Urgan and the stolen cattle: Cgm 51 f. 84va 27-31; Ranke 15965-15969
Tristan stabs Urgan in the eye: Cgm 51 f. 84va 39-85ra 3; Ranke 15978-16036
Tristan severs Urgan’s hand: Cgm 51 f. 85ra 13-21; Ranke 16046-16054
Tristan pushes Urgan down the ravine: Cgm 51 f. 85va 10-18; Ranke 16164-16174
Tristan gives Gilan Urgan’s severed hand: Cgm 51 f. 85va 32-34; Ranke 16190-16192
Tristan gives Petitcriu to a jester: Cgm 51 f. 85va 49-51, 87ra 1-9; Ranke 16271-16283
The messenger gives Petitcriu to Isolde: Cgm 51 f. 87ra 10-25; Ranke 16284-16300
Isolde shows Petitcriu to Marke: Cgm 51 f. 85ra 47-rb 13; Ranke 16333-16351
Battle in front of a city:
Marke bans Tristan and Isolde from court: Cgm 51 f. 88ra 8-rb 40; Ranke 16535-16620
Tristan and Isolde leave the court and go into the woods: Cgm 51 f. 88rb 41-va 42; Ranke 16621-16630
Marke observes Tristan and Isolde sleeping in the grotto: Cgm 51 f. 92ra 7-vb 4; Ranke 17485-17616
Marke lets Tristan and Isolde back to court: Cgm 51 f. 93rb 10-19; Ranke 17712-17722
Marke discovers Tristan and Isolde sleeping together in the orchard: Cgm 51 f. 95ra 16-rb 8; Ranke 18192-18230
Marke comes back with the witnesses: Cgm 51 f. 95vb 6-29; Ranke 18367-18404
Tristan and Kahedin’s friendship: Cgm 51 f. 96vb 18-31/97ra 5-10; Ranke 18738-18751/18766-18771
Tristan and Kahedin fight against Kahedin’s enemies: Cgm 51 f. 96vb 18-31/97ra 5-10; Ranke 18738-18751/18766-18771
Tristan and Curvenal, disguised as heralds, visit Isolde and Brangäne: Cgm 51 lacuna; Kehrt 2285-2420
Tristan disguised as a fool in front of Marke and Isolde: Cgm 51 lacuna; Kehrt 2516-2538
Tristan beats Antrit with the club: lacuna in Cgm 51; Kehrt 2539-2564
Antrit pulls Tristan off of Isolde: Cgm 51 lacuna; Kehrt 2539-2564
Tristan pops Melot’s eye: Cgm 51 102rb 8-26; Kehrt 2637-2655
Marke leaves for the hunt: Cgm 51 102rb 27-31; Kehrt 2656-2660
Antrit discovers Tristan and Isolde sleeping together: Cgm 51 102va 31-vb 4; Kehrt 2705-2722
Tristan beats King Marke with the club: Cgm 51 102vb 19-37; Kehrt 2737-2755
Tristan kills Pleherin with his club: Cgm 51 102vb 38-103ra 14; Kehrt 2756-2776
Tristan slips away on a rowboat: Cgm 51 103ra 22-25; Kehrt 2784-2787
Marke chases Tristan, who escapes across the sea: Cgm 51 103ra 31-rb 9; Kehrt 2793-2813
Cassie hands down the key to her fortress to Kahedin:
Kahedin embraces Cassie in the courtyard: Cgm 51 105va 31-vb 8; Kehrt 3131-3166
Tristan and Kahedin ride away; Kahedin loses his schapel: Cgm 51 105vb 9-23; Kehrt 3167-3181
Nampotenis shows Kahedin’s schapel to Cassie: Cgm 51 105vb 24-42; Kehrt 3182-3204
Kahedin is killed while fighting against Nampotenis: Cgm 51 105vb 43-106rb 16; Kehrt 3205-3272
Tristan brings back Kahedin’s corpse: Cgm 51 106rb 17-23; Kehrt 3273-3279
Isolt Whitehand and Tristan cry on Kahedin’s coffin: Cgm 51 106rb 24-33; Kehrt 3280-3289
Tristan, dying, asks a merchant to make Isolde sail to him: Cgm 51 106va 3-33; Kehrt 3304-3334
Isolde sails towards Tristan: Cgm 51 106vb 22-25; Kehrt 3376-3379
Isolde dies on Tristan’s coffin; Marke finds the dead lovers: Cgm 51 108ra 1-rb 38; Kehrt 3402-3489
Marke brings the lovers’ coffins back home: Cgm 51 108rb 39-va 1; Kehrt 3490-3499
A vine and a rosebush grow out from the lovers’ tombs: Cgm 51 108va 10-vb 21; Kehrt 3508-3627 + 3696-3703
Marke gives up the crown and wears the monk robe: Cgm 51 108vb 27-38; Kehrt 3671-3682

seg.said: Daz sich ich wol, z<.> dirre s<...>

div2.ab: Âwe, der nôt! Verstu von mir, ich bin tôt!
Got gnade der sele din. | Du wer ein helt untz an den tot din.
Âwê und âwê, | wir gesehen dich niemer mê
Der himel und erde geschaffen hat. | Er pflege siner <.>agerat | und laze si im bevolhen sin | uf die gnade sin
Omnia vincit amor, sed nos cedamus amori.
Swer die werlt minnet, | dar an im misselinget.
Âwê frowe reine, | du list hie aleine, || von deiner minne bistu tôt! | Daz ist maniges hertzen nôt!
Liet deiu marschalchinne | eines seliges sunes inne
Omnia que discis non aufert fur neque piscis
Tristran ist chomen heim ze L<....>

back.note: On fols. 7r, 7v, 11r and 11v the strips are coloured with a light brown tint.
The bird is retouched.
The silhouette of a lady, on the left, was trimmed off.
The letters are displayed vertically.
The letters are displayed upside down.
Unique instance of a coat of arms (a rampant lion?) depicted on a shield.
All helmets depicted in the illustrations are of the type called Topfhelm (en. ‘pot helm’ or ‘great helm’), which was used between 1200 and 1250 (Gichtel, pp. 80-81).
The crown worn on the helmet indicates a king (cp. l. 1123: “ein kunec, geriten in sin lant”).
The knight lances are represented with a simple pen stroke.
Gichtel, p. 100, reads s<tunt>.
Cp. l. 1280: “ein sloz si vür die tür do stiez”.
Blanscheflur wears a brown garb used by beggars (cp. l. 1267: “eines armen betewibes cleit”).
The messenger wears a Taphart (Gichtel, p. 101 n. 80).
On this f. the upper strip is preserved, while elsewhere it was trimmed/cut off.
On f. 11v the backgrounds are not coloured; instead, the strips are coloured with a light brown tint.
The gesture of the messenger’s left hand seems to hint at the inscription within the scroll above, as a kind of manicula.
On the priest’s missal a quotation from Psalm 129,1.
This inscription is a rewording of Gottfried’s text. Cp. l. 1166: “Blanscheflur, diu reine” and ll. 1181-1183: “mit also clegelicher not, | dazs einen anderen tot, | der niht vor minnen wære komen”.
Inner quotation of ll. 1931-1932: “diu guote marschalkinne | læg eines sunes inne”.
The nurse’s face is retouched.
The baby’s silouhette is retouched.
The scenes are not separated.
The boys’ faces are retouched.
This inscription is a palimpsest and, beneath the quotation from Psalm 111, traces of an older script are visible but not clearly understandable.
Beneath this inscription traces of an older script are visible.
Quotation from the Golden Sequence, with a variation (reple is not in the standard version).
This skill is not mentioned in Gottfried’s poem, but it complies with Eilhart’s Tristrant (l. 142: “werfen mit den steinen”).
Gichtel, p. 106: Harfenzither; the inscription above calls this instrument Rotta.
The silouhette of the boy was added secondarily (Kunerth 1999, p. 43).
On this f. the upper strip is preserved, while elsewhere it was trimmed/cut off.
Tristran’s hat indicates that he is coming back from a journey.
Cp. l. 4009: “an vüezen und den beinen bar”.
Rual wears a hat (l. 4068: “ein hüetelin”), that indicates his role as merchant, since Tristan had said he was the son of a merchant from Parmenie (cp. ll. 3099, 3282, 4055, 4081).
Rual and Tristan hold hands: cp. l. 4073 “Tristan der nam in an die hant”.
Silver page numbering above the crown.
This inscription is misplaced, since the character beneath is not Rual.
For Blanscheflur’s ring, cp. ll. 4286-4287 (“Rual der guote bot im do | ein vingerlin an sine hant”) and Marke’s words, l. 4294-4295 (“a, sprach er, sueziu swester, | diz vingerlin daz gab ich dir”).
Hands/fingers complementing speech indicate the speakers.
The three scenes are not separated.

The gap was differently filled, cp. Gichtel 1979, p. 108 (“tristan der swertdegen”) and Kunerth 1999, p. 94 and note 375 (“tristan ter swert tragen” - Karin Schneider saw here an older inscription, 13th century, later retouched).
In the text it is Marke who gives Tristan the sword. Cp. ll. 5019-5021 (“Marke nam dô Trstanden | sînen neven ze handen, | swerte unde sporn stricte er im an").
On this f. the upper strip is preserved, while elsewhere it was trimmed/cut off.
This inscription is retouched.
This inscription is retouched and is almost unreadable. Gichtel 1979, p. 109, proposes to read either lande or kanoel; cp. Kunerth 1999, p. 95 (“chanoel”).
Cp. ll. 5346-5347: “den waren pavelune | und hüten uf daz gras geslagen”.

The silouhette on the right margin was trimmed off. Gichtel 1979, p. 109, says that this third hunter keeps two hounds on a leash and that there is a tree in the background: at the present state, all this seems to have been cut off or have faded.
